Context:
Program Name: Heating, Refrigeration, and Air Conditioning Technology
Code: T162
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $3,966.00 *
International Tuition: $18,001.00 **
Program Location: Casa Loma Campus
Centre: Construction & Engineering Technologies
School: Apprenticeship & Skilled Trades
Available Semesters for Domestic Students: Fall 2024, Winter 2025
Available Semesters for International Students: Open (Check admission dates)
Program Description: Provides students with an understanding of designing, building, controlling, and maintaining energy-efficient building environmental systems. Practical skills development in the first two years through hands-on projects in shops, with a focus on commercial systems in the third year to succeed in the HVAC industry.
* Domestic tuition is subject to change based on government policies.
** International tuition is subject to change and may vary depending on student visa status and program delivery mode.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Heating, Refrigeration, and Air Conditioning Technology Program T162 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
This advanced diploma program at George Brown College focuses on the heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration (HVAC/R) industry. In the first two years, students learn about residential and some light commercial systems, with the third year dedicated to commercial systems. The curriculum covers the theory of air and hydronic systems for designing distribution systems and selecting appropriate fans, pumps, heating and cooling systems, and controls for larger buildings.

The program adheres to industry-standard design practices for environmentally responsible and energy-efficient residential, commercial, and industrial systems as established by HRAI, ASHRAE, and the Canada Green Building Council.

Upon completion of this program, graduates can challenge the Gas Fitter 2 provincial qualification exam and obtain certification if they achieve a passing grade of 75%. In semester 3, students are assisted in preparing to challenge the Ontario Ministry of Consumer Affairs and Housing HVAC House exam, which, when passed with a score of 75%, can be used toward obtaining a Building Code Identification Number (BCIN).

Graduates may find employment opportunities in consulting engineering and architectural firms, design/build contractors, school boards, commercial refrigeration installation and maintenance companies, building automation and control companies, building maintenance, HVAC/R manufacturing, sales, and distribution companies. They may also pursue management careers in the mechanical sector of the construction industry or become self-employed specialty contractors.

Required courses for semester 1 include: BLDG 1086 – Building Science and Green Technologies, and HVAC 1001 – Refracement Systems Fundamentals.

Context:
Program Name: COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication)
Prerequisite: None mentioned in text but COMM 1000 is mentioned before COMM 2000
Non-graduation requirement: Yes, this course does not count towards graduation and has additional charge.
Location for more information: Assessment Centre
General Education Electives: Not mentioned in text
Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Relate effectively to heating, ventilation, air conditioning and refrigeration supervisors, coworkers and customers.
2. Comply with applicable acts, regulations, legislation and codes to maintain personal and public safety.
3. Solve scientific, mathematical and engineering problems related to designing, operating and installing energy systems for commercial and industrial complexes.
4. Prepare and analyze detailed drawings, and compile technical specifications for energy systems.
5. Design, operate and install energy systems for commercial and industrial complexes.
6. Develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development that lead to enhanced work performance and career opportunities, and keep pace with industry changes.
Tuition & Fees:
Domestic Students: $3,966.00 (estimated total for first two semesters)
International Students: $18,001.00 (estimated total for first two semesters)
Additional Costs: Not mentioned in text but includes books which are to be purchased separately.
Financial Assistance: Approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet eligibility criteria.
Disclaimer: The information contained in this website is subject to change without notice.
Admission Requirements: Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (not specified if it's required or minimum).

**Note:** \*\* indicates that the information was already mentioned earlier in the text but is repeated for completeness.

Context:
* Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent is required.
* Minimum grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U).
* Minimum grade 12 English (C or U) for applicants with OSSD.
* Mature students should be 19 years of age or older and have no OSSD.
* Mature students can take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math, or upgrade to achieve required credits.
* Course exemptions are available based on college or university credits.
* International Students should visit the George Brown College Online Application System to apply.
* Contact information for School of Apprenticeship and Skilled Trades: Phone: 416-415-5000, ext. 6711; Email: skilledtrades@georgebrown.ca; Office: Casa Loma Campus, Room E308.
* Contact the College through their Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
* International students can contact a recruitment representative specialized by country of origin through the International Contact Us page.
* Campus tours and information sessions are available for interested individuals.
* Programs related to Heating, Refrigeration, and Air Conditioning Technician (T160), Electrical Techniques (T167), Plumbing Techniques (T165) are offered.
